text: I think that's the hard thing about being an entrepreneur. There are periods of time where you have to make judgment calls that are not going to be the consensus view. You got to have confidence in your convictions on how to best play the hand.
speaker: Eric Simons
context: Lenny asks Eric about the counterintuitive lessons from StackBlitz's journey, particularly building technology first and then finding a problem to solve later. Eric explains how during the 2020-2021 period when companies were pressured to grow rapidly and increase headcount, StackBlitz chose to remain conservative with their burn rate and team size. He emphasizes that entrepreneurs must sometimes make decisions that go against popular opinion at the time.
text_ko: 그게 창업가(entrepreneur)로 사는 가장 힘든 점인 것 같아요. 어떤 때는 대다수의 의견(consensus view)과 다른 판단(judgment calls)을 내려야 할 때가 있어요. 그럴 때는 주어진 상황을 어떻게 가장 잘 풀어갈지에 대한 내 신념(convictions)을 믿고 자신감을 가져야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得做创业者最难的就是，有时候你得做一些决定，而这些决定大家可能都不认同。你必须对自己的判断有信心，知道怎么把手里的牌打好。
text_es: Creo que eso es lo más difícil de ser emprendedor. Hay momentos en los que tienes que tomar decisiones que no van a ser del agrado de todos. Tienes que tener confianza en tus convicciones sobre cómo jugar mejor tus cartas.

text: It was kind of like, Bolt's this overnight success, seven years in the making.
speaker: Eric Simons
context: Lenny discusses how people often don't see the years of work that preceded Bolt's explosive growth. Eric acknowledges this perception paradox - while Bolt appears to be an instant hit that went from zero to massive revenue in months, it was actually built on seven years of developing the underlying WebContainer technology at StackBlitz. This phrase captures the reality that many 'sudden' successes are actually the result of long periods of preparation and groundwork.
text_ko: 뭔가 그랬어요. Bolt가 하룻밤 사이에 뜬 것처럼 보이지만, 사실은 7년을 공들여 만든 성공이에요.
text_zh: 这就像是说，Bolt是个一夜成名的公司，但其实背后默默耕耘了七年。
text_es: Fue algo así como que Bolt se convirtió en un éxito de la noche a la mañana, pero que en realidad le tomó siete años construir.

text: Most importantly, it's been the people. It's rare to find startups where you have the core group of five, six, seven people that have been there for five years plus.
speaker: Eric Simons
context: Lenny asks how StackBlitz managed to grow so rapidly with such a small team of about 20 people. Eric explains that their success stems from having a stable core team that has worked together for over five years, which is uncommon in Silicon Valley where people typically stay at startups for only one or two years. This stability allowed them to take long-term bets and maintain high levels of trust and context across the team.
text_ko: 무엇보다 사람들 덕분이었어요. 다섯, 여섯, 일곱 명 정도의 핵심 멤버가 5년 넘게 함께한 스타트업은 찾기 정말 드물어요.
text_zh: 最关键的还是人，真的很难得能找到一个创业公司，核心团队五六个人、六七个人能一起干五年以上的。
text_es: Lo más importante ha sido la gente. Es muy difícil encontrar startups donde tengas un grupo central de cinco, seis, siete personas que lleven ahí más de cinco años.

text: There's some amount of, there's feedback from the customers of, 'This thing didn't taste good.' And then there's like, 'Hey, we've been cooking something interesting, and this tastes... I don't know. This, I think you're going to like this. I think this is a killer dish.' And so you kind of have to balance those things.
speaker: Eric Simons
context: Lenny asks about how StackBlitz prioritizes features given the overwhelming number of requests from their million monthly active users. Eric uses a restaurant chef analogy to explain their approach to product development. He describes the balance between responding to direct customer feedback about problems versus proactively building new capabilities that customers haven't explicitly requested but that the team believes will be valuable.
text_ko: 고객들한테서 '이건 맛이 별로였어'라는 피드백도 있고, 반면에는 '우리가 뭔가 흥미로운 걸 만들었는데, 이건… 글쎄. 근데 넌 이거 좋아할 거야. 진짜 킬러 요리(killer dish)야'라고 내부에서 열광하는 경우도 있어요. 그래서 그런 것들 사이에서 균형을 잘 맞춰야 해요.
text_zh: 客户会给我们反馈说"这个东西不好吃"。但同时我们也会想"嘿，我们正在研发一些有意思的东西，这个味道...怎么说呢，我觉得你们会喜欢的，我觉得这绝对是个爆款产品"。所以你得在这两者之间找个平衡。
text_es: Hay cierta cantidad de feedback de los clientes que dicen "Esto no sabía bien." Pero también está el "Oye, hemos estado cocinando algo interesante, y esto sabe... no sé. Esto, creo que te va a encantar. Creo que este plato va a arrasar." Entonces tienes que equilibrar esas dos cosas.

text: And I think it's actually, largely, a function of just years of experience doing it. I think if you kind of rewound 10 years ago, I would have had really no, I wouldn't have had just the years of getting my butt kicked by the free market, to have cultivated a sense of this stuff.
speaker: Eric Simons
context: Eric continues explaining how he decides what features to prioritize at StackBlitz. He reflects on how product intuition develops over time through experience. Eric acknowledges that his ability to make good product decisions comes from years of trial and error in the startup world, where the market has repeatedly tested and refined his judgment about what customers actually want versus what they say they want.
text_ko: 사실 이건 대부분 그냥 오랜 시간 직접 해오면서 쌓인 경험의 결과예요. 10년 전으로 되돌려놓으면 솔직히 전혀 그럴 수 없었을 거예요. 자유시장(free market)에서 얻어맞아가며 쌓은 시간이 없었으니까요.
text_zh: 我觉得这主要就是多年实战经验积累出来的。你想啊，要是倒回十年前，我根本就没有这种感觉，毕竟还没有被自由市场摩擦那么多年，也就培养不出这种嗅觉来。
text_es: Y creo que en realidad es, en gran parte, cuestión de años de experiencia haciéndolo. Creo que si regresáramos 10 años atrás, yo no habría tenido, simplemente no habría tenido esos años de que el mercado libre me diera una paliza tras otra, para haber desarrollado un sentido para estas cosas.

text: And when you think about, 'Okay, how would you best interact with an AI developer agent?' It's basically that. You really want to be good at defining scope, and helping it go and debug various things, or whatever have you. There's a huge overlap of the skill set of being a rock star PM, and being really good at using, frankly, any of these text to apps or Cogen tools.
speaker: Eric Simons
context: Eric discusses the limitations of Bolt and explains who tends to be most successful with the tool. He notes that the most successful non-developer users are typically product managers because they already possess skills that translate well to working with AI coding tools. Eric argues that PMs' expertise in defining project scope and directing developers makes them naturally good at prompting and guiding AI agents to build software effectively.
text_ko: 그리고 '자, AI 개발자 에이전트(AI developer agent)랑 어떻게 가장 잘 상호작용할까?'라고 생각해보면, 사실 핵심은 그거예요. 범위를 잘 정의하고, 에이전트가 가서 여기저기서 문제를 찾아 디버깅하게 도와줄 줄 알아야 해요. 스타 PM(rock star PM)이 갖춘 스킬셋과, 솔직히 말하면 이런 텍스트-투-앱(text to apps)이나 코겐 도구(Cogen tools)를 잘 다루는 능력은 많은 부분이 겹쳐요.
text_zh: 你想想，"怎么跟AI开发助手最好地配合呢？" 其实就是这样。你得擅长定义范围，帮它去调试各种问题什么的。做一个超牛的PM(产品经理)需要的技能，和熟练使用这些文本转应用工具或者代码生成(Cogen)工具需要的技能，基本上是重叠的。
text_es: Y cuando lo piensas, "Bueno, ¿cuál sería la mejor manera de interactuar con un agente desarrollador de IA?" Básicamente es eso. Realmente necesitas ser bueno definiendo el alcance del proyecto, y ayudándolo a debuggear varias cosas, o lo que sea que necesites. Hay una coincidencia enorme entre las habilidades de ser un PM estrella, y ser realmente bueno usando, la verdad, cualquiera de estas herramientas de texto a apps o de Cogen.
